trans-unit.source: Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with Azure Active Directory authentication
trans-unit.target: Create a .NET MVC web app in Azure App Service with Azure Active Directory authentication

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in Azure App Service that authenticates with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in Azure App Service that authenticates with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> using <linkText>Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title> as the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to create an ASP.NET MVC line-of-business application in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title> using <linkText>Azure Active Directory</linkText><title></title> as the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: You will also learn how to use the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Graph Client Library</linkText><title></title> to query directory data in the application.
trans-unit.target: You will also learn how to use the <linkText>Azure Active Directory Graph Client Library</linkText><title></title> to query directory data in the application.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Active Directory tenant that you use can be an Azure-only directory, or it can be directory-synced with your on-premise Active Directory (AD) to create a single sign-on experience for workers that are on-premise or remote.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Active Directory tenant that you use can be an Azure-only directory, or it can be directory-synced with your on-premise Active Directory (AD) to create a single sign-on experience for workers that are on-premise or remote.

trans-unit.source: For Azure App Service Web Apps you can configure authentication against an Azure Active Directory tenant with a few clicks of a button.
trans-unit.target: For Azure App Service Web Apps you can configure authentication against an Azure Active Directory tenant with a few clicks of a button.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Use Active Directory for authentication in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You will build a simple line-of-business Create-Read-Update-Delete (CRUD) application in App Service Web Apps that tracks work items with the following features:
trans-unit.target: You will build a simple line-of-business Create-Read-Update-Delete (CRUD) application in App Service Web Apps that tracks work items with the following features:

trans-unit.source: Authenticates users against Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Authenticates users against Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Implements sign-in and sign-out functionality
trans-unit.target: Implements sign-in and sign-out functionality

trans-unit.source: Uses [Authorize] to authorize users for different CRUD actions
trans-unit.target: Uses [Authorize] to authorize users for different CRUD actions

trans-unit.source: Queries Azure Active Directory data using <linkText>Azure Active Directory Graph API</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Queries Azure Active Directory data using <linkText>Azure Active Directory Graph API</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Uses <linkText>Microsoft.Owin</linkText><title></title> (instead of Windows Identity Foundation, i.e. WIF), which is the future of ASP.NET and much simpler to set up for authentication and authorization than WIF
trans-unit.target: Uses <linkText>Microsoft.Owin</linkText><title></title> (instead of Windows Identity Foundation, i.e. WIF), which is the future of ASP.NET and much simpler to set up for authentication and authorization than WIF

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: You need the following to complete this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You need the following to complete this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: An Azure Active Directory tenant with users in various groups
trans-unit.target: An Azure Active Directory tenant with users in various groups

trans-unit.source: Permissions to create applications on the Azure Active Directory tenant
trans-unit.target: Permissions to create applications on the Azure Active Directory tenant

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure SDK 2.5.1</linkText><title></title> or later
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure SDK 2.5.1</linkText><title></title> or later

trans-unit.source: The sample application in this tutorial, <linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet</linkText><title></title>, is created by the Azure Active Directory team and can be used as a template to create new line-of-business applications with ease.
trans-unit.target: The sample application in this tutorial, <linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet</linkText><title></title>, is created by the Azure Active Directory team and can be used as a template to create new line-of-business applications with ease.

trans-unit.source: It has the following built-in features:
trans-unit.target: It has the following built-in features:

trans-unit.source: Uses <linkText>OpenID Connect</linkText><title></title> to authenticate with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Uses <linkText>OpenID Connect</linkText><title></title> to authenticate with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Roles controller that contains an Azure Active Directory search filter and enables you to easily map Azure Active Directory users or groups to application roles.
trans-unit.target: Roles controller that contains an Azure Active Directory search filter and enables you to easily map Azure Active Directory users or groups to application roles.

trans-unit.source: Sample TaskTracker controller that demonstrates how you can authorize different roles for specific actions in the application, including the standard usage of [Authorize].
trans-unit.target: Sample TaskTracker controller that demonstrates how you can authorize different roles for specific actions in the application, including the standard usage of [Authorize].

trans-unit.source: Clone or download the sample solution at <linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet</linkText><title></title> to your local directory.
trans-unit.target: Clone or download the sample solution at <linkText>WebApp-GroupClaims-DotNet</linkText><title></title> to your local directory.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> to set up the Azure Active Directory application and project.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> to set up the Azure Active Directory application and project.

trans-unit.source: The permissions configured in the Azure Active Directory application requires the User role; not Global Administrator.
trans-unit.target: The permissions configured in the Azure Active Directory application requires the User role; not Global Administrator.

trans-unit.source: Once you're finished configuring the application, type F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Once you're finished configuring the application, type F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: Once the application loads, click Sign In.
trans-unit.target: Once the application loads, click Sign In.

trans-unit.source: If you configured the Azure Active Directory application properly and set the corresponding settings in Web.config, you should be redirected to the log in.
trans-unit.target: If you configured the Azure Active Directory application properly and set the corresponding settings in Web.config, you should be redirected to the log in.

trans-unit.source: Simply log in with the account you used to create the Azure Active Directory application in the Azure portal, since it's the Azure Active Directory application's default owner.
trans-unit.target: Simply log in with the account you used to create the Azure Active Directory application in the Azure portal, since it's the Azure Active Directory application's default owner.

trans-unit.source: In Startup.Auth.cs of the sample project, note that the application has a method called AddOwnerAdminClaim, which it uses to add the application owner into the Admin role.
trans-unit.target: In Startup.Auth.cs of the sample project, note that the application has a method called AddOwnerAdminClaim, which it uses to add the application owner into the Admin role.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to immediately start managing application roles in the Roles controller.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to immediately start managing application roles in the Roles controller.

trans-unit.source: Once signed in, click Roles to manage application roles.
trans-unit.target: Once signed in, click Roles to manage application roles.

trans-unit.source: In Search for Users/Groups, start typing the desired user name or group name and notice that a dropdown list shows a filtered list of users and/or groups from your Azure Active Directory tenant.
trans-unit.target: In Search for Users/Groups, start typing the desired user name or group name and notice that a dropdown list shows a filtered list of users and/or groups from your Azure Active Directory tenant.

trans-unit.source: In Views\Roles\Index.cshtml, you will see that the view uses a JavaScript object called AadPicker (defined in Scripts\AadPickerLibrary.js) to access the Search action in the Roles controller.
trans-unit.target: In Views\Roles\Index.cshtml, you will see that the view uses a JavaScript object called AadPicker (defined in Scripts\AadPickerLibrary.js) to access the Search action in the Roles controller.

trans-unit.source:
var searchUrl = window.location.protocol + "//" + window.location.host + "/Roles/Search";
...
var picker = new AadPicker(searchUrl, maxResultsPerPage, input, token, tenant);
In Controllers\RolesController.cs, you will see the Search action, which sends the actual request to the Azure Active Directory Graph API and returns the response back to the page.
trans-unit.target:
var searchUrl = window.location.protocol + "//" + window.location.host + "/Roles/Search";
...
var picker = new AadPicker(searchUrl, maxResultsPerPage, input, token, tenant);
In Controllers\RolesController.cs, you will see the Search action, which sends the actual request to the Azure Active Directory Graph API and returns the response back to the page.

trans-unit.source: Later, you will use the same method to create simple functionality in your application.
trans-unit.target: Later, you will use the same method to create simple functionality in your application.

trans-unit.source: Select a user or group from the dropdown, select a role, and click Assign Role.
trans-unit.target: Select a user or group from the dropdown, select a role, and click Assign Role.

trans-unit.source: Here, you will publish the application to a web app in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: Here, you will publish the application to a web app in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: There are already instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> for deploying to App Service Web Apps, but those steps also annul the configuration for your local debug environment.
trans-unit.target: There are already instructions at <linkText>README.md</linkText><title></title> for deploying to App Service Web Apps, but those steps also annul the configuration for your local debug environment.

trans-unit.source: I'll show you how to deploy while preserving the debug configuration.
trans-unit.target: I'll show you how to deploy while preserving the debug configuration.

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Select Microsoft Azure Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Select Microsoft Azure Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't signed in to Azure, click Sign In and use the Microsoft account for your Azure subscription to sign in.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't signed in to Azure, click Sign In and use the Microsoft account for your Azure subscription to sign in.

trans-unit.source: Once signed in, click New to create a new web app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Once signed in, click New to create a new web app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Fill in all required fields.
trans-unit.target: Fill in all required fields.

trans-unit.source: You will need a database connection for this application to store role mappings, cached tokens, and any application data.
trans-unit.target: You will need a database connection for this application to store role mappings, cached tokens, and any application data.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Once the web app is created, the Publish Web dialog is opened.
trans-unit.target: Once the web app is created, the Publish Web dialog is opened.

trans-unit.source: In Destination URL, change http to https.
trans-unit.target: In Destination URL, change http to https.

trans-unit.source: Copy the entire URL to a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Copy the entire URL to a text editor.

trans-unit.source: You will use it later.
trans-unit.target: You will use it later.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Next.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Next.

trans-unit.source: Clear the Enable Organizational Authentication checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Clear the Enable Organizational Authentication checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Instead of clicking Publish to go through with the web publish, click Close.
trans-unit.target: Instead of clicking Publish to go through with the web publish, click Close.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes to save the changes to the publishing profile.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes to save the changes to the publishing profile.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure management portal, go to your Azure Active Directory tenant and click the Applications tab.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure management portal, go to your Azure Active Directory tenant and click the Applications tab.

trans-unit.source: Click Add at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click Add at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Select Web Application And/Or Web API.
trans-unit.target: Select Web Application And/Or Web API.

trans-unit.source: Give the application a name and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Give the application a name and click Next.

trans-unit.source: In App Properties, set Sign-On URL to the web app URL that you saved earler (e.g. https://.azurewebsites.net), and the APP ID URI to https:///. Then, click Complete.
trans-unit.target: In App Properties, set Sign-On URL to the web app URL that you saved earler (e.g. https://.azurewebsites.net), and the APP ID URI to https:///. Then, click Complete.

trans-unit.source: Once the application is created, click Configure.
trans-unit.target: Once the application is created, click Configure.

trans-unit.source: Under Keys, create a new key by selecting 1 year in the dropdown.
trans-unit.target: Under Keys, create a new key by selecting 1 year in the dropdown.

trans-unit.source: Under Permissions to other applications, for the Azure Active Directory entry, select Access your organization's directory in the Delegated Permissions dropdown.
trans-unit.target: Under Permissions to other applications, for the Azure Active Directory entry, select Access your organization's directory in the Delegated Permissions dropdown.

trans-unit.source: The exact permissions you need here depends on the desired functionality of your application.
trans-unit.target: The exact permissions you need here depends on the desired functionality of your application.

trans-unit.source: Some permissions require the Global Administrator role to set, but the permissions required by this tutorial only requires the User role.
trans-unit.target: Some permissions require the Global Administrator role to set, but the permissions required by this tutorial only requires the User role.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: Before you navigate away from the saved configuration page, copy the following information into a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Before you navigate away from the saved configuration page, copy the following information into a text editor.

trans-unit.source: Client ID
trans-unit.target: Client ID

trans-unit.source: Key (if you navigate away from the page, you will not be able to see the key again)
trans-unit.target: Key (if you navigate away from the page, you will not be able to see the key again)

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open Web.Release.config in your project. Insert the following XML into the tag, and replace the value of each key with the information that you saved for your new Azure Active Directory application.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open Web.Release.config in your project. Insert the following XML into the tag, and replace the value of each key with the information that you saved for your new Azure Active Directory application.

trans-unit.source: <appSettings> <add key="ida:ClientId" value="
trans-unit.target: <appSettings> <add key="ida:ClientId" value="

trans-unit.source: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> <add key="ida:AppKey" value="
trans-unit.target: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> <add key="ida:AppKey" value="

trans-unit.source: [e.g. rZJJ9bHSi/cYnYwmQFxLYDn/6EfnrnIfKoNzv9NKgbo=]
trans-unit.target: [e.g. rZJJ9bHSi/cYnYwmQFxLYDn/6EfnrnIfKoNzv9NKgbo=]

trans-unit.source: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> <add key="ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri" value="
trans-unit.target: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> <add key="ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri" value="

trans-unit.source: [e.g. https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/]
trans-unit.target: [e.g. https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/]

trans-unit.source: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> </appSettings>
trans-unit.target: " xdt:Transform="SetAttributes" xdt:Locator="Match(key)" /> </appSettings>

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the value of ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri ends with a slash "/".
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the value of ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri ends with a slash "/".

trans-unit.source: Right-click your project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click your project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish to publish to Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish to publish to Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, you have two Azure Active Directory applications configured in the Azure management portal: one for your debug environment in Visual Studio, and one for the published web app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, you have two Azure Active Directory applications configured in the Azure management portal: one for your debug environment in Visual Studio, and one for the published web app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: During debugging, the app settings in Web.config are used to make your Debug configuration work with Azure Active Directory, and when it's published (by default, the Release configuration is published), a transformed Web.config is uploaded that incorporates the app setting changes in Web.Release.config.
trans-unit.target: During debugging, the app settings in Web.config are used to make your Debug configuration work with Azure Active Directory, and when it's published (by default, the Release configuration is published), a transformed Web.config is uploaded that incorporates the app setting changes in Web.Release.config.

trans-unit.source: If you want to attach the published web app to the debugger (you must upload debug symbols of your code in the published web app), you can create a clone of the Debug configuration for Azure debugging, but with its own custom Web.config transform (e.g. Web.AzureDebug.config) that uses the Azure Active Directory settings from Web.Release.config.
trans-unit.target: If you want to attach the published web app to the debugger (you must upload debug symbols of your code in the published web app), you can create a clone of the Debug configuration for Azure debugging, but with its own custom Web.config transform (e.g. Web.AzureDebug.config) that uses the Azure Active Directory settings from Web.Release.config.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to maintain a static configuration across the different environments.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to maintain a static configuration across the different environments.

trans-unit.source: In this part of the tutorial, you will learn how to build out the desired line-of-business functionality based on the sample application.
trans-unit.target: In this part of the tutorial, you will learn how to build out the desired line-of-business functionality based on the sample application.

trans-unit.source: You will create a simple CRUD work items tracker, similar to the TaskTracker controller but using standard CRUD scaffolding and design pattern.
trans-unit.target: You will create a simple CRUD work items tracker, similar to the TaskTracker controller but using standard CRUD scaffolding and design pattern.

trans-unit.source: You will also use the included Scripts\AadPickerLibrary.js to enrich your application with data from the Azure Active Directory Graph API.
trans-unit.target: You will also use the included Scripts\AadPickerLibrary.js to enrich your application with data from the Azure Active Directory Graph API.

trans-unit.source: In the Models folder, create a new model called WorkItem.cs, and replace the code with the code below:
trans-unit.target: In the Models folder, create a new model called WorkItem.cs, and replace the code with the code below:

trans-unit.source: Open DAL\GroupClaimContext.cs and add the highlighted code:
trans-unit.target: Open DAL\GroupClaimContext.cs and add the highlighted code:

trans-unit.source: public DbSet<WorkItem> WorkItems { get; set; }
trans-unit.target: public DbSet<WorkItem> WorkItems { get; set; }

trans-unit.source: public DbSet<TokenCacheEntry> TokenCacheEntries { get; set; } }
trans-unit.target: public DbSet<TokenCacheEntry> TokenCacheEntries { get; set; } }

trans-unit.source: Build the project to make your new model accessible to the scaffolding logic in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Build the project to make your new model accessible to the scaffolding logic in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Add a new scaffolded item WorkItemsController to the Controllers folder.
trans-unit.target: Add a new scaffolded item WorkItemsController to the Controllers folder.

trans-unit.source: To do this, right-click Controllers, point to Add, and select New scaffolded item.
trans-unit.target: To do this, right-click Controllers, point to Add, and select New scaffolded item.

trans-unit.source: Select MVC 5 Controller with views, using Entity Framework and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select MVC 5 Controller with views, using Entity Framework and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Select the model that you just created and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select the model that you just created and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\WorkItemsController.cs
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\WorkItemsController.cs

trans-unit.source: Add the highlighted [Authorize] decorations to the respective actions below.
trans-unit.target: Add the highlighted [Authorize] decorations to the respective actions below.

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Observer, Writer, Approver")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Observer, Writer, Approver")]

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]

trans-unit.source: public ActionResult Create() ...
trans-unit.target: public ActionResult Create() ...

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]

trans-unit.source: public async Task<ActionResult> Create([Bind(Include = "ItemID,AssignedToID,AssignedToName,Description,Status")] WorkItem workItem) ...
trans-unit.target: public async Task<ActionResult> Create([Bind(Include = "ItemID,AssignedToID,AssignedToName,Description,Status")] WorkItem workItem) ...

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]

trans-unit.source: public async Task<ActionResult> Edit(int? id) ...
trans-unit.target: public async Task<ActionResult> Edit(int? id) ...

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer")]

trans-unit.source: public async Task<ActionResult> Edit([Bind(Include = "ItemID,AssignedToID,AssignedToName,Description,Status")] WorkItem workItem) ...
trans-unit.target: public async Task<ActionResult> Edit([Bind(Include = "ItemID,AssignedToID,AssignedToName,Description,Status")] WorkItem workItem) ...

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer, Approver")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer, Approver")]

trans-unit.source: public async Task<ActionResult> Delete(int? id) ...
trans-unit.target: public async Task<ActionResult> Delete(int? id) ...

trans-unit.source: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer, Approver")]
trans-unit.target: [Authorize(Roles = "Admin, Writer, Approver")]

trans-unit.source: Since you take care of role mappings in the Roles controller, all you need to do is make sure that each action authorizes the right roles.
trans-unit.target: Since you take care of role mappings in the Roles controller, all you need to do is make sure that each action authorizes the right roles.

trans-unit.source: You may have noticed the [ValidateAntiForgeryToken] decoration on some of the actions.
trans-unit.target: You may have noticed the [ValidateAntiForgeryToken] decoration on some of the actions.

trans-unit.source: Due to the behavior described by <linkText>Brock Allen</linkText><title></title> at <linkText>MVC 4, AntiForgeryToken and Claims</linkText><title></title> your HTTP POST may fail anti-forgery token validation because:
trans-unit.target: Due to the behavior described by <linkText>Brock Allen</linkText><title></title> at <linkText>MVC 4, AntiForgeryToken and Claims</linkText><title></title> your HTTP POST may fail anti-forgery token validation because:

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory does not send the http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/identityprovider, which is required by default by the anti-forgery token.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory does not send the http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/identityprovider, which is required by default by the anti-forgery token.

trans-unit.source: If Azure Active Directory is directory synced with AD FS, the AD FS trust by default does not send the http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/identityprovider claim either, although you can manually configure AD FS to send this claim.
trans-unit.target: If Azure Active Directory is directory synced with AD FS, the AD FS trust by default does not send the http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/identityprovider claim either, although you can manually configure AD FS to send this claim.

trans-unit.source: You will take care of this in the next step.
trans-unit.target: You will take care of this in the next step.

trans-unit.source: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs, add the following line of code in the ConfigureAuth method:
trans-unit.target: In App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs, add the following line of code in the ConfigureAuth method:

trans-unit.source: ClaimTypes.NameIdentifies specifies the claim http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier, which Azure Active Directory does supply.
trans-unit.target: ClaimTypes.NameIdentifies specifies the claim http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier, which Azure Active Directory does supply.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have taken care of the authorization part (seriously, that didn't take long), you can devote your time to the actual functionality of the actions.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have taken care of the authorization part (seriously, that didn't take long), you can devote your time to the actual functionality of the actions.

trans-unit.source: In Views\WorkItems\Create.cshtml (an automatically scaffolded item), find the Html.BeginForm helper method and modify it as follows:
trans-unit.target: In Views\WorkItems\Create.cshtml (an automatically scaffolded item), find the Html.BeginForm helper method and modify it as follows:

trans-unit.source: @using (Html.BeginForm(
trans-unit.target: @using (Html.BeginForm(

trans-unit.source: "Create", "WorkItems", FormMethod.Post, new { id = "main-form" }
trans-unit.target: "Create", "WorkItems", FormMethod.Post, new { id = "main-form" }

trans-unit.source: , @type="hidden"
trans-unit.target: , @type="hidden"

trans-unit.source: id="submit-button"
trans-unit.target: id="submit-button"

trans-unit.source: In the script, the AadPicker object searches the ~/Roles/Search action for Azure Active Directory users and groups that match the input.
trans-unit.target: In the script, the AadPicker object searches the ~/Roles/Search action for Azure Active Directory users and groups that match the input.

trans-unit.source: Then, when the submit button is clicked, the AadPicker object saves the user ID to the hidden AssignedToID field.
trans-unit.target: Then, when the submit button is clicked, the AadPicker object saves the user ID to the hidden AssignedToID field.

trans-unit.source: Now either run the app in the Visual Studio debugger or publish to Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Now either run the app in the Visual Studio debugger or publish to Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Log in as the application owner and navigate to ~/WorkItems/Create.
trans-unit.target: Log in as the application owner and navigate to ~/WorkItems/Create.

trans-unit.source: For my published line-of-business app, I navigate to https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/WorkItems/Create.
trans-unit.target: For my published line-of-business app, I navigate to https://mylobapp.azurewebsites.net/WorkItems/Create.

trans-unit.source: You'll see now that you you can use the same AadPicker search filter to pick an Azure Active Directory user.
trans-unit.target: You'll see now that you you can use the same AadPicker search filter to pick an Azure Active Directory user.

trans-unit.source: Fill out the rest of the form and click Create.
trans-unit.target: Fill out the rest of the form and click Create.

trans-unit.source: The ~/WorkItems/Index page now shows the newly created work item.
trans-unit.target: The ~/WorkItems/Index page now shows the newly created work item.

trans-unit.source: You'll also notice in the screenshot below that I removed the AssignedToID column in Views\WorkItems\Index.cshtml.
trans-unit.target: You'll also notice in the screenshot below that I removed the AssignedToID column in Views\WorkItems\Index.cshtml.

trans-unit.source: Now, make similar changes to the Edit view.
trans-unit.target: Now, make similar changes to the Edit view.

trans-unit.source: In Views\WorkItems\Edit.cshtml, make the changes to the Html.BeginForm helper method that are identical to the ones for Views\WorkItems\Create.cshtml in the previous step (replace "Create" with "Edit" in the highlighted code above).
trans-unit.target: In Views\WorkItems\Edit.cshtml, make the changes to the Html.BeginForm helper method that are identical to the ones for Views\WorkItems\Create.cshtml in the previous step (replace "Create" with "Edit" in the highlighted code above).

trans-unit.source: That's it!
trans-unit.target: That's it!

trans-unit.source: Now that you have configured the authorizations and line-of-business functionality for the different actions in the WorkItems controller, you can try to log in as users of different application roles.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have configured the authorizations and line-of-business functionality for the different actions in the WorkItems controller, you can try to log in as users of different application roles.
